content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; REFERENCE." is a condensed version of the previous information provided. The "Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003" acknowledges the importance of the nation's defense and the sacrifices made by military personnel. Hundreds of thousands of reservists and National Guard members have been called to active duty, putting their lives on hold to serve their country with distinction. The "Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003" emphasizes supporting military members during their transition into and out of active duty. References in the Act are to the Higher Education Act of 1965. The "Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003" focuses on supporting military members during their transition into and out of active duty, with a waiver authority for response to military contingencies and national emergencies. The "Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003" allows the Secretary of Education to waive or modify provisions related to student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Act during a war, military operation, or national emergency to prevent financial harm to affected individuals. The "Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003" allows the Secretary of Education to modify administrative requirements for student financial assistance to ease the burden on affected individuals. Adjustments can be made to the calculation of need for financial assistance to account for sums received during a crisis. The "Higher Education Relief Opportunities for Students Act of 2003" allows modifications to be made to the calculation of financial assistance for affected individuals, including adjustments to the amount required to be returned in case of overpayment by institutions participating in student assistance programs under title IV of the Act. Student assistance programs under title IV of the Act in disaster areas may receive temporary relief from certain requirements during a national emergency. The Secretary will publish necessary waivers or modifications in the Federal Register. The Secretary may issue waivers or modifications for student assistance programs under title IV of the Act in disaster areas during a national emergency. Terms and conditions will be provided, and the impact of these waivers will be reported to relevant committees after 15 months. The Secretary can issue waivers or modifications for student assistance programs in disaster areas during a national emergency. Recommendations for changes to statutory or regulatory provisions will be included in the report on the impact of these waivers. Sections 482(c) and 492 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 do not apply to the waivers and modifications authorized by this Act. SEC. 3. Tuition refunds or credits for members of armed forces. Sense of Congress is that institutions should provide full refunds to students affected by active duty, and minimize enrollment deferral for those withdrawing. Full refund defined as tuition and fees refund or credit for future use. SEC. 4. USE OF PROFESSIONAL JUDGMENT. A financial aid administrator can adjust expected student or parent contributions if documented. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "active duty" refers to service excluding training or school attendance. An "affected individual" includes those on active duty during war, National Guard duty, residing in a disaster area, or facing economic hardship due to war or national emergency. The term "serving on active duty during a war or other military operation or national emergency" includes service by Reserve or retired members of an Armed Force ordered to active duty for such purposes. The term "qualifying National Guard duty during a war or other military operation or national emergency" refers to full-time National Guard duty for more than 30 consecutive days in connection with such events. Title 32, United States Code, applies to National Guard duty during a war, military operation, or national emergency declared by the President with Federal funds. The provisions of this Act will end on September 30, 2005.
